{"title":"Page 16","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"If!
greater value will be imparted by this road to our
more fertile lands, in this most beautiful and healthful region of ours 1 But if it only equalled that
of Georgia, the landed value must be increased to
' nearly $140,000,000 over what it now is! But
the first railroad running from the city of Boston
was commenced in 1834. That year the value of
all the property of Boston was $21,590,300, while
in 1849 (the same period as taken for the State)
it was $102,827,500 ! and on the 1st day of January, 1851, it had advanced to $238,000,000!
exhibiting an increase of $225,000,000 in sixteen
years! With such facts before us, can we slumber,
or hesitate to subscribe the $1,600,000, or even
$2,000,000, if necessary, to make this road, with
such prospects before us, and such examples to
stimulate our energies 1 If Massachusetts, with
her barren, frozen, hilly, rocky soil, by her railroads, can work such wonders for her great
commercial emporium, what is there too extravagant to say, must be the result to New Orleans,
from developing this magnificent, but now tied up
portion of our State, itself three times as large as
Massachusetts 1 Should we not arouse as one
man, and subscribe this stock, that New Orleans,
like Boston, may pour this more than $200,000,000
into her pockets; and distribute the thrice told
$290,000,000 of Massachusetts to the parishes
along the line of this great highway.
But some contend that by making a short road,
from Donaldsonville out to Grand Lake, at a cost
of $250,000, an outlet is furnished for the Attakapas ; and by making another from St. Landry
